Award.AwardTitle: Pricing Services and Products in the Presence of Parallel Delivery Mechanisms and Strategic Consumer Behavior

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Delivery mechanisms are the processes by which firms sell their products and services to customers. For example, in online marketplaces, some sellers choose to sell their products at a fixed posted price, whereas others solicit bids and sell to the highest bidder. There have been many studies comparing the benefits of different delivery mechanisms to sellers and customers under the assumption that sellers offer their products through a single delivery mechanism. However, firms increasingly offer their products and services through multiple delivery mechanisms in parallel, allowing their customers to choose among the delivery mechanisms. The goal of this project is to develop models and algorithms to help sellers choose which delivery mechanisms to operate in parallel, what prices to charge in each delivery mechanism, and how to allocate limited service capacity among the different delivery mechanisms. The models and algorithms developed within the scope of this project will enable sellers to maximize their revenue, while providing more effective service to their customers.

A key difficulty in the analysis of parallel delivery mechanisms is that the customers are strategic, and their decision to make use of a particular delivery mechanism depends on the decisions of the seller and of other customers. This dependence requires analyzing the equilibrium resulting from customers' and seller's decisions by using tools from game theory and stochastic models. Computation of equilibria is provably hard. This project will identify conditions under which equilibria exist and will characterize the structure of strategies employed by customers in equilibrium. This characterization will be used to identify the features of customers who make use of a particular delivery mechanism, make design decisions on prices and service capacities used in different delivery mechanisms, and to find the optimal amount of information sharing between the seller and the customers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Service systems often offer their services through multiple modes that
differ not only in the price but also the service quality, such as
priority with which a customer is served. This project developed
models, algorithms and computational framework to understand how such
service and delivery modes should be designed for the benefit of the
customers as well as for improving the operation of the service
system. To achieve this goal, it is crucial to accurately capture,
through realistic behavioral models, how customers respond to the
operational and design choices made by the service system. This
project used methods and modeling techniques from the fields of game
theory, economics, and stochastic modeling to develop equilibrium
models to capture customer behavior and analyzed using these models
the design choices made by one or more service systems. In addition,
these stochastic models were used to develop a computational and
simulation framework for numerically finding the market outcomes, both
in monopolistic settings with a single service system and in
competitive settings with multiple service systems. The results of
these investigations continue to be useful in informing market
operation and design in different settings such as quality competition
among services, long-term price competition among firms, `add-on
items'' recommendation in online markets, as well as information
sharing in ride-hailing marketplaces.

The results from this research project also contributed to and had
impact on other disciplines. In particular, the research contributes
to the application of auction theory in the realm of service systems,
and to the theory of constrained mechanism design. The work on sharing
of information in ride-hailing markets contributes to the practical
applications of information design (an emerging topic in economics).

The research done during the course of this project have been
disseminated to the academic community as well as to industry
practitioners through peer-reviewed academic publications in top
international journals and seminars/talks at international
conferences. Furthermore, the research has formed the core of the two
PhD theses, and thus has been directly instrumental in the training of
the next generation of academics and practitioners. Finally, the
models and the results from this project were incorporated into the
graduate curriculum, via two PhD courses offered to graduate students
in fields such as Operations Research, Economics, Electrical
Engineering and Operations Management.
